item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÊñ∞Â®òÂú®Â§ß‰∏≠Â§ÆËΩ¶Á´ô‰∏æË°åÊ¢¶ÂπªÂ©öÁ§º‚ÄîËøôÊòØÂçÅÂ§öÂπ¥Êù•Ê†áÂøóÊÄßÁöÑ‰∏≠ÂøÉÔºö ‚ÄúÊúâÂè≤‰ª•Êù•ÊúÄÂ•ΩÁöÑÊ¥æÂØπ‚Äù
item.description:
Meredith Giuliani always fantasized about saying ‚ÄúI do‚Äù on a¬†grand¬†scale.¬†

So, hosting her over-the-top nuptials in Grand Central Terminal was nothing short of a splashy dream come true.¬†

‚ÄúWe just thought, ‚ÄòHow cool would it be to turn one of New York‚Äôs most stunningly beautiful landmarks into a main character at our wedding?‚Äô‚Äù Giuliani, 32, an Upper West Side transplant from New Jersey, told The Post, joking that the transit hub acted as the architectural ‚Äúbest man‚Äù for the f√™te.¬†

Giuliani, a strategy and operations manager for a tech startup ‚Äî and no relation to former Big Apple mayor Rudy Giuliani ‚Äî exchanged vows with groom David Garrett, 32, a corporate real estate expert, in the legendary terminal‚Äôs Vanderbilt Hall on Oct. 11.¬†

It was a supersized spectacle ‚Äî officiated by NFL Hall of Famer and New York Giants veteran Harry Carson ‚Äî made complete¬†by 12-foot floral installations, golden mirrored flooring, a harpist and violinist duet, and a faux, old-timey ticketing booth.¬†

At the ticket stand, designed by Giuliani, the couple‚Äôs 340 guests were given customized train tickets inked with their seating assignments for the reception celebration at A-list hotspot Cipriani.¬†

The luxe lovebirds were the first to officially transform Grand Central Terminal into a wow-worthy wedding venue in more than a decade ‚Äî and they did it big, committed to having ‚Äúthe best party ever,‚Äù Giuliani told The Post.¬†

‚ÄúWe have such an amazing group of friends and family,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe wanted to make this an amazing experience for them.‚Äù

While the newlywed chose not to disclose the cost of her NYC extravaganza, Aaron Donovan, a spokesperson for the MTA, which oversees all Grand Central Terminal operations, told The Post that renting Vanderbilt Hall can come with a price tag ranging between $25,000 and $40,000.¬†

The price tag varies ‚Äúdepending on the amount of space and time requested, [as well as the] logistics and staffing needed to redirect the public to trains,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúAdditional fees to secure space controlled by Grand Central retailers, such as Vanderbilt Hall‚Äôs Grand Brasserie, could more than double that cost.‚Äù

The couple did, in fact, rent it out to limit commuter foot traffic during their sacred shindig.¬†

Giuliani‚Äôs mother and father, a software procurement specialist, as well as her in-laws, who work in healthcare administration, footed the bill for their behemoth of a big day, she said.¬†

But before attendees feasted on filet mignon and Chilean sea bass at the ritzy Cipriani, the rarefied bride walked down the aisle in a custom ballgown, speckled in sparkles and feathers, by haute couturier Ysa Makino.¬†

She and Garrett shared their first kiss as husband and wife directly beneath the vintage clock overlooking Vanderbilt Hall ‚Äî the historic hub‚Äôs main waiting room-turned-public event space.¬†Built in 1913 and restored in 1998, the approximately 6,000-square-foot spot features 55-foot ceilings and two gold chandeliers.

Swanky soir√©es like theirs can be difficult to orchestrate, according to Donovan.¬†

‚ÄúThe MTA is delighted to be able to host weddings at Grand Central‚Äôs iconic Vanderbilt Hall, but they are challenging to support due to requirements to allow continuing public access,‚Äù he said.¬†

David Florio, the MTA‚Äôs chief real estate transactions and operations officer, told The Post that pairs considering a Grand Central Terminal wedding should begin making arrangements at least 11 months in advance.¬†

Giuliani began planning her chic soir√©e at the Midtown marvel in September 2024, just a few short months after Garrett popped the question in May of last year, on Little Island along the West Side Highway.¬†

The millennial said she insisted her guy propose in a popular area, where passersby would ooh and ahh at the touching scene. She recreated the look-at-me moment on her special day last week, snapping photos in front of Grand Central‚Äôs 42nd Street and Park Avenue entrance, as well as inside the station‚Äôs main concourse.¬†

‚ÄúStrangers were taking pictures and videos of us, and we loved it,‚Äù gushed Giuliani, who‚Äôll soon change her last name to Garrett. ‚ÄúIt was so overwhelmingly positive ‚Äî people were congratulating us, complimenting my dress and wishing us well for the future.‚Äù

She cherishes the memory as her and Garrett‚Äôs way of sharing their love with the boroughs in which they fell in love. The honeys plan to honeymoon in the Maldives next month.¬†

‚ÄúWe have so much to thank this city for,‚Äù said Giuliani. ‚ÄúWe feel really grateful and honored to be able to do this really crazy and unique thing in a city that means so much to us.‚Äù
item.author: Asia Grace

item.title: Âú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Âú∞ÈìÅÁ´ôË¢´ÁñØÂ≠êÊùÄÂÆ≥ÁöÑÂøÉÁà±ÁöÑ‰øùÂÆâ‰∫∫ÂëòÂú®Â∏ÉÈ≤ÅÂÖãÊûóÈÜíÊù•Êó∂ÂìÄÊÇºÔºö ‚ÄúÁ≤æÂΩ©ÔºåÂÖ≥ÊÄÄÔºå‰∫∫ÊÄßÂåñ‚Äù
item.description:
A beloved Italian churchgoer who was ruthlessly beaten to death outside a Brooklyn subway station was remembered for his kindness, cheerful laugh and unwavering faith, as more than 100 family members and friends gathered Friday night to honor his life.

Nicola Tanzi, 64, was killed on Oct. 7 when a recidivist psycho savagely attacked him for no reason as the devout Catholic held a door open at the Jay Street-MetroTech Station ‚Äì near where he had worked as a security guard for 15 years.¬†

‚ÄúJust a wonderful, caring, human being,‚Äù David Tanzi said of his uncle during a somber wake held at Andrew Torregrossa & Sons Funeral Home in Brooklyn.

‚Äú[He] would do anything for anybody and his faith. He had an infectious laugh. I think if you asked anybody that had met him, that would remind anybody of him now.‚Äù

The Italian-born victim moved to New York City decades ago, living a quiet and simple life in Bensonhurst ‚Äî without a cell phone or email ‚Äî working as a MetroTech public safety officer and volunteering at his local churches.

A devoted parishioner at St. Dominic‚Äôs Church who was also active at Sacred Hearts of Mary and Jesus & St. Stephen Roman Catholic Church in Carroll Gardens, Tanzi is survived by his five brothers.

‚ÄúHe was a simple guy,‚Äù Tanzi‚Äôs devastated younger brother Anthony told The Post, noting that his slain sibling had planned to retire in June and relocate to Long Island.

‚ÄúHe never had an email, he never had a cell phone. That‚Äôs the way he liked it. He was involved in a lot of things‚Ä¶a lot more things than I‚Äôd ever do. He decided he was going to retire‚Ä¶to come out to Long Island and do all the things we used to do as kids. He never go the chance. He was robbed.‚Äù

Tanzi was cremated before the solemn wake, with his urn placed at the front of the chapel, surrounded by a sea of flowers and photos.

Richard Ravaloi, who met Tanzi in junior high when they were both 15, sobbed as he described one of his closest friends ‚Äî a ‚Äúnice guy‚Äù who he said didn‚Äôt deserve the ‚Äúsenseless‚Äù beatdown that ended his life.

‚ÄúNicky was always in a good mood, laughing and joking,‚Äù Ravaloi said.

‚ÄúHe was just a nice guy, you know. He‚Äôd never hurt anybody. He was just nice to be around. He was never in a bad mood. He went to work, and back everyday from that subway station. To have something like that happen, and the way that it did, he didn‚Äôt deserve that.‚Äù

David Mazariegos, 25, was charged with first-degree murder for the merciless attack.

Prosecutors said the brute, who has five open criminal cases, sucker-punched the Italian immigrant twice in the face, knocking him to the floor, before reportedly kicking his face and body even after Tanzi was completely unconscious.

Tanzi ‚Äî who died hours later ‚Äî suffered a skull fracture, a crushed nasal bone, and multiple other facial injuries.

The crazed attacker allegedly confessed that he resented having a door held open for him, boasting to police that he took Tanzi‚Äôs ‚Äúspirit‚Äù because he didn‚Äôt like the way he looked at him, prosecutors said.

Mazariegos is being held at Rikers Island without bail.
item.author: Ella Morrison, Anna Young

item.title: Â∏ÉÈ≤ÅÂÖãÊûóÊ∞ë‰∏ªÂÖöÈ¢ÜÂØº‰∫∫Âú®Ë±™ÂçéÊôöÈ§ê„ÄÅÈÖíÂ∫ó‰∏äËä±Ë¥π‰∫ÜÊï∞ÂçÉÁæéÂÖÉ‚ÄîÂ∞ΩÁÆ°Á¶ªÂºÄ‰∫ÜÂäûÂÖ¨ÂÆ§ÔºöËÆ∞ÂΩï
item.description:
A longtime Brooklyn Democratic Party leader has spent more than $14,000 in political committee cash on pricey dinners, hotel stays and even a theater ticket membership ‚Äî despite leaving office last year, The Post has learned.

Lori Knipel ‚Äî a Brooklyn district leader for over 30 years ‚Äî retired from her position in the 44th Assembly District in September 2024.¬†

But she‚Äôs continued to expense meals at restaurants, cellphone and internet bills, Amazon purchases, groceries and more at least 71 times since then, according to disclosure filings for her authorized multi-candidate committee ‚Äî of which she is the sole member.

The state records show a whopping $7,069 of the expenses alone were simply marked ‚Äúmiscellaneous.‚Äù

The post-retirement spending could potentially violate state election laws, which dictate strict rules on how ‚Äúleftover‚Äù campaign committee money can be spent prior to the entity‚Äôs official termination, experts said.

According to the Campaign Finance Handbook, remaining funds ‚Äúmust be legally dispersed‚Äù by either charitable or political donations, a transfer to another committee, a refund to contributors or simply turning them over to the New York State General Fund prior to termination.

Rules on ‚Äúleftover‚Äù funds are unequivocal, said election lawyer Ben Kallos, a former City Council member for Manhattan.

‚ÄúI never paid for meals as a candidate,‚Äù Kallos said.

‚ÄúCandidates should not be using their account funds as piggy banks for second homes or dining out.‚Äù¬†

Former Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum added: ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt sound good.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs no longer a district leader, right? So why would [she] be using any of her funds for anything other than turning them over to the various places you‚Äôre supposed to turn them over to?‚Äù

Knipel, 71, insisted that she hadn‚Äôt done anything wrong when contacted by The Post this week.

‚ÄúNone of this is against the law,‚Äù she said Friday, ‚Äúand everything that has done [sic] is in compliance with the law.‚Äù

A deeper review by The Post of the campaign committee records show similar meals and other expenses from Knipel‚Äôs last years in office, including at out-of-state restaurants, hotels and for an internet provider in Pennsylvania.

Between 2022 and her latest filing on July 15, Knipel has spent $16,309 at restaurants, records show, with a total of 144 itemized meals on the record, plus $24,945 in un-itemized ‚Äúmeal‚Äù and ‚Äúfood‚Äù spending for a total of $41,254.

Several of her apparent favorite Brooklyn eateries, including Skinflints where she spent a total $1,174 over that time frame ‚Äî and Spring Garden ($2,465), Golden Z ($940) and Mancini‚Äôs ($820) ‚Äî were outside of Knipel‚Äôs 44th Assembly District, which covers Park Slope, Windsor Terrace and Kensington.¬†

But the dining out went far beyond the borough, with her disclosures listing restaurants in Manhattan, Queens, Hicksville, Hauppauge, and as far as Portland, ME, as well as several visits to a sleepy town in the Poconos.

State election law allows for a broad usage of campaign and political committee money ‚Äî and doesn‚Äôt prohibit meals as long as they are related to official duties ‚Äî but funds may never be used for personal use at any time.

‚ÄúThe prohibition against personal use remains throughout,‚Äù a state Board of Elections spokesperson told The Post, though district leaders in the past have had apparent issues with complying.

When asked for details about the meals, Knipel said that she received reimbursement for them because she is ‚Äútaking meetings on the phone, Zoom meetings,‚Äù and that ‚Äúit‚Äôs ok, because I am working constantly.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is perfectly legal,‚Äù Knipel added, of the 31 PA-based meals expensed since 2022, adding that she has a second home in the state, which could explain $69.99 spent on a PA-based internet provider in 2024, according to the filings.

Campaign and elections lawyer Paul Newell ‚Äî also a Manhattan district leader ‚Äî said her explanation was tenuous, at best.

‚ÄúI do not believe that taking a phone call during a meal makes that meal a legitimate expense,‚Äù Newell told The Post.

Standards for spending funds are ‚Äúvery clear and very obvious,‚Äù said Gotbaum, the former public advocate.

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt a difficult standard to keep,‚Äù she said of her time in office.

‚ÄúWe are elected to do one thing, but we‚Äôre not elected to do things for ourselves.‚Äù

Knipel added that some of the PA meals were with members of the Brooklyn Democratic Club, but refused to specify who ‚Äî and then accused the Post reporter of writing a ‚Äúhatchet hit‚Äù because she hasn‚Äôt endorsed Democratic mayoral nominee, Zohran Mamdani.

Knipel said her political committee, called Brooklyn Independent Democrats, is actually a club, and that any spending is related to political actions of the club by ‚Äúeither myself or somebody else in the club.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúThe only reason it was reimbursed to me is because I laid out the money for others,‚Äù Knipel claimed.¬†

‚ÄúEverything I do is associated with the Democratic Party in one way or another,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúdoing work on my own time without any compensation.

‚ÄúI should be compensated in some way as I am doing this work,‚Äù she said.

Despite the committee containing disclosure records dating back to 2002, none of the politicos or election lawyers The Post spoke with had ever heard of it ‚Äî and no digital footprint for it appears online.

A 2022 form filed out by the committee treasurer lists Knipel as the only member of the multi-candidate committee.

Sources said Knipel should be lauded for her dedication to poll workers and for pro-bono legal work she has done in the community.

‚ÄúIt is not an easy job that takes true dedication and time without any compensation,‚Äù Knipel wrote in a 2022 district leader questionnaire, where she also advocated for more transparency of party finances.
item.author: Peter Senzamici

item.title: Êó†ÂÆ∂ÂèØÂΩíÁöÑÈôåÁîü‰∫∫Âú®È´òÂ≥∞Êó∂ÊÆµÂÜ≤Á™ÅÊúüÈó¥Âú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Âú∞ÈìÅÁ´ôÂÜÖÂà∫‰º§‰∫Ü51Â≤ÅÁöÑÁî∑Â≠êÔºöË≠¶ÂØüÔºåÊ∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫ê
item.description:
A homeless, ‚Äúemotionally disturbed‚Äù man with nearly a dozen prior busts stabbed a 51-year-old straphanger inside a Greenwich Village subway station during the Thursday morning rush ‚Äì knifing him in the back moments after the two feuded on board a train, cops and sources said.

The two men ‚Äì who did not know each other ‚Äì clashed on board a Brooklyn-bound D train at West 4th Street around 7:30 a.m., cops said.

As the pair got off the train, the suspect ‚Äì later identified as Justice Jackson, 30 ‚Äî knifed the victim in the back, cops and sources said.

The victim was taken by EMS workers to Bellevue Hospital, where he was listed in stable condition, police said.¬†

Meanwhile, Jackson ‚Äî seen in a surveillance image wearing dark gray sweatpants, a black shirt and black slippers ‚Äî hopped back on the train, sources said.¬†

He was arrested more than 24 hours after the attack ‚Äì around 1 p.m. Friday ‚Äì and charged with both felony and misdemeanor assault, cops said.¬†

Jackson has 11 previous arrests on his record ‚Äî and is known as both a grand larceny recidivist and a repeat offender in the city‚Äôs transit system, the sources said.

His last arrest was in July, for three separate grand larceny cases, according to the sources.

Police also responded to 10 incidents involving Jackson as an ‚Äúemotionally disturbed person,‚Äù according to the sources.

He was hospitalized following his Friday arrest, according to police, but it was not immediately clear why.

Felony assaults within the city‚Äôs transit system have seen a slight uptick so far this year, with 453 reported compared to the 445 at this time in 2024, according to the latest NYPD data, released on Sunday.¬†

However, overall felony crime on the rails is down by about 4%, with 1,639 incidents reported compared to 1,706 during the same time last year, statistics show.¬†
item.author: Joe Marino, Amanda Woods

item.title: Andrew CuomoÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂÖ¨ÂÖ±Â∏ÇÈïøÁ´ûÈÄâÊó∂Èó¥Ë°®ËÆ©ÂÜÖÈÉ®‰∫∫Â£´ÊÑüÂà∞Âõ∞ÊÉëÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫‰ªñËØïÂõæËµ∂‰∏äZohran Mamdani
item.description:
He‚Äôs Andrew Cuo-No-Show.

Mayoral contender Andrew Cuomo has taken 10 days off publicly campaigning since Labor Day weekend, a Post analysis shows ‚Äî as insiders express disbelief he isn‚Äôt pounding the pavement to catch up to Zohran Mamdani before November.

The former governor‚Äôs apparent aloof persona contrasts wildly with his rivals Mamdani, the socialist Democratic nominee, and GOP standard bearer Curtis Sliwa, who‚Äôve daily shown face across the Big Apple since Aug. 31.

Many insiders were baffled that Cuomo, an independent candidate who‚Äôs consistently polling in second place to Mamdani, isn‚Äôt doing more to make up ground and sway voters.

‚ÄúEspecially in October, you want to be [at] half a dozen events a day if nothing else but for optics,‚Äù said a longtime Democratic campaigner.

‚ÄúIf not now when? Now is the time.‚Äù

Cuomo only had public events 36 days following the Labor Day holiday weekend marking the unofficial start of the general election campaign, his schedule shows.

Many of those events were announced mere hours, sometimes minutes, before they happened.

Only 17 days since the general election campaign‚Äôs kickoff involved multiple appearances ‚Äî with the vast majority on the weekends, focused on the religious circuit.

Cuomo campaign officials argued that he has held private meetings and other events during the days he didn‚Äôt have a public schedule.

‚ÄúAndrew Cuomo has been working 24 hours a day during this general election meeting voters, courting supporters and doing local and national media interviews to amplify his message,‚Äù said campaign spokesperson Rich Azzopardi.

Still, the apparent voters-at-a-distance schedule is reminiscent of Cuomo‚Äôs Democratic primary campaign, which he entered as the front-runner before losing to Mamdani in historic fashion.

The most recent polling, conducted by Fox News and released Thursday, shows Mamdani finally cracking the 50% threshold of likely voters, with Cuomo trailing at 28% and Sliwa at 13%.

‚ÄúIf he had been on Church Avenue walking up and down it a year ago, he wouldn‚Äôt be in this f‚Äîing position,‚Äù a frustrated longtime Cuomo backer said.

‚ÄúIt almost seems corporate and highbrow. I just don‚Äôt think that we are pounding the streets with enthusiasm and verve. And that‚Äôs what Mamdani has.‚Äù

Mamdani has generally held at least one event a day, pressing the flesh with voters even though he‚Äôs the clear front-runner with little room for unforced errors that could harm his campaign, his schedule shows.

And Sliwa has held more public events this week than Cuomo had since Labor Day.

Following the first general mayoral election debate Thursday, Mamdani held a ‚Äúreverse town hall‚Äù while Sliwa held a news conference on subway crime and attended the wake of a security guard who was viciously beaten to death.

Cuomo held no public events Friday.

The three-term Democratic governor has blamed his loss in the June primary on running a campaign that wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúaggressive‚Äù enough and that didn‚Äôt acknowledge the power of social media ‚Äî unlike Mamdani‚Äôs TikTok-heavy effort.

As Cuomo mounted his independent bid, he admitted to donors he made mistakes and needed to show face with voters.

When asked what he learned from his loss during Thursday‚Äôs debate, Cuomo said: ‚ÄúI did not do enough on social media, which is a very effective medium.‚Äù

The ex-gov‚Äôs campaign and his allies have been much more active on X and social media platforms since the primary, including putting out viral videos hammering Mamdani and even sitting down for an interview with influencer Logan Paul.

But some insiders said it‚Äôs too late to make up the ground ‚Äî regardless of what tack Cuomo‚Äôs campaign takes.

‚ÄúCuomo has no mathematical path to victory at this juncture. It‚Äôs too late to improve his weak ground game. Barring a seismic event, Mamdani is on a glide path to victory,‚Äù said Democratic consultant Chris Sosa.

‚ÄúCuomo can blame social media all he wants. But the problem with the Cuomo campaign comes down to one factor: most voters cannot stand Andrew Cuomo. Shaking more hands won‚Äôt fix such a fundamental flaw.‚Äù
item.author: Craig McCarthy, Matthew Fischetti, Matt Troutman

item.title: ÁîòÊØîËØ∫Êö¥Âæí‚Äú‰πî¬∑Â∏ÉÈ≤ÅÂÖãÊûó‚Äù ÔºåÂè¶Â§ñ6ÂêçÊô∫ËÄÖË≠¶ÂØüÂõ†Êö¥Âäõ‰ºÅÂõæÊé•ÁÆ°Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁöÑÂûÉÂúæÂú∫ËÄåËÆ§ÁΩ™
item.description:
They‚Äôre taking a whack at coming clean.

Gambino crime family capo Joseph ‚ÄúJoe Brooklyn‚Äù Lanni and six of his fellow wiseguys copped guilty pleas Friday for violently trying to take over the Big Apple‚Äôs garbage business.

‚ÄúI knew that agreeing to do this was against the law,‚Äù Lanni flatly said, apparently reading a boilerplate definition of racketeering during his plea in Brooklyn federal court.

Lanni, 54, who also goes by the mafia moniker ‚ÄúMommino,‚Äù headed a sprawling racketeering enterprise engaging in extortion, witness retaliation and other crimes ‚Äî with an audacious bid to put the city‚Äôs trash and demolition industry under its thumb, federal prosecutors said.

The pleas follow a probe from the Eastern District of New York feds that led to a 16-count indictment in 2023.

An ensuing takedown, including arrests in Italy, rounded up a crew of Gambino made men and associates with nicknames such as ‚ÄúVinny Slick,‚Äù ‚ÄúUncle Ciccio,‚Äù ‚ÄúTwin‚Äù and ‚ÄúFifi.‚Äù

Made man Diego ‚ÄúDanny‚Äù Tantillo, 50, wore flashy silver sunglasses in the courtroom as he pleaded guilty to charges related to extorting a New York City-area carting business.

Tantillo menacingly threatened the business‚Äô owner with a metal baseball bat, demanding monthly payments, court papers state.

When the owner stopped making payments, Tantillo‚Äôs men set fire to the man‚Äôs front steps, let air out of the tires of his trucks and even threatened to cut him in half, the documents allege.

One mobster ‚Äî Francesco ‚ÄúUncle Ciccio‚Äù Vicari, 64, who also pleaded guilty Friday ‚Äî ‚Äúacted like the ‚ÄòLast of the Samurai'‚Äù as he picked up a knife and told an associate to bisect the hapless owner, a wiretap revealed.

‚ÄúGet this axe and you make him ‚Äì two,‚Äù he allegedly said.

Tantillo, who also allegedly arranged a hammer assault on another demolition company‚Äôs employee, received at least $4 million in payments from his ill-gotten schemes ‚Äî and dutifully ‚Äúkicked up‚Äù the proceeds to Lanni, prosecutors said.

Lanni was also implicated, but not charged, along with Vincent ‚ÄúVinny Slick‚Äù Minsquero, 38, in a wild fracas in a Toms River, New Jersey restaurant in September 2023, court documents allege.

The mobbed-up pair got in an argument with another patron, prompting the restaurant‚Äôs staff to ask them to leave.

Minsquero damaged a painting and punched wall, while Lanni said he would ‚Äúburn this place down with you in it,‚Äù court papers state.

Minutes after making the threat, Lanni bought a red gas container, walked to a pump and tried to fill it before Minsquero wrested it from him, the documents reveal.

Still fuming, Lanni called the restaurant 39 times ‚Äî with one threatening call being captured on Toms River cop‚Äôs body camera.

‚ÄúApologize to me,‚Äù Lanni could be heard saying, the documents state, before he repeated, ‚ÄúBeg for my forgiveness. Beg for my forgiveness. Beg for my forgiveness . . . Beg. Beg. Beg for my forgiveness. Beg. Beg. Beg for my forgiveness. Say, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm sorry, Joe.‚Äô‚Äù

The ordeal didn‚Äôt end there ‚Äî two men came back to the restaurant around midnight, punched the owner in the head, put a knife to his neck and threatened to kill him, court papers state.

The owner‚Äôs spouse was also knocked to the ground and beat by the two men.

‚ÄúGet this axe and you make him ‚Äì two.‚Äù

Judge Frederic Block, a joke-cracking wiseguy of the standup comedy variety, told Lanni he faced a sentencing range between 6.5 and 8 years, before implying the ultimate prison bit could be shorter.

‚ÄúYou are putting your life in my hands,‚Äù the judge said, before deadpanning, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm talking real street talk to you.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre willing to roll the dice?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, your honor,‚Äù Lanni replied.
item.author: Ben Kochman, Matt Troutman

item.title: ÈïøÂ≤õÂ∞èÂ≠¶ÊïôÂ∏àÂú®ÂçßÂ∫ïÂà∫‰º§ÂêéË¢´ÊçïÔºåÊçÆÁß∞Êö¥Èú≤‰∫Ü‰ªñÂØπÂ•≥Â≠©ÁöÑËâ≤ÊÉÖÁü≠‰ø°Ôºå 13
item.description:
The now-suspended Long Island elementary school teacher caught sexting someone he believed was a 13-year-old girl was arrested on Friday ‚Äî as 76-pages of sick chat logs came to light.

Mark Verity, 37, was charged with trying to send sexual messages to a minor and attempting to involve the child in a sex act after getting caught up in a sting operation run by Predator Poachers Long Island.

Verity, a music teacher at Wading River Elementary School, was taken into custody following a two-day investigation sparked by the vigilante group‚Äôs viral video confrontation ‚Äî in which the married dad of two allegedly admitted to the sick exchange.

In the disturbing text messages, Verity can be seen reaching out to the organization‚Äôs onine decoy in early October.¬†

Verity started flirting with the decoy, who told him she was in middle school ‚Äî even though she was¬†a 29-year-old group member using AI to make herself appear younger,¬†the messages revealed.¬†

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre very cute,‚Äù Verity told the girl through Kik, a popular messenger and social media app, according to the documents.¬†

In under an hour, the pair moved the conversation to Snapchat ‚Äî where Verity began getting overtly sexual with the decoy, asking for nude photos, trying to arrange a meet up for sex, and telling her he was in a relationship already but that won‚Äôt stop him from being with her, the messages read.¬†

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre prettier anyway ‚Äî I‚Äôd make sure you got the same attention,‚Äù Verity told the teen about his wife, who is also an elementary teacher in the same district.¬†

The 15-year veteran teacher then asked the teen to share her cup-size and detail how far she has gone with boys in the past, the documents detailed.¬†

The decoy responded that she has only kissed a boy her age before, to which Verity told her that he‚Äôll help her practice and said that she has ‚Äúgreat lips for kissing,‚Äù according to the files.¬†

As the conversation continues, Verity starts pushing for the decoy to send him sexually explicit photos of herself in hot pink panties, specifically, and asks for her to stand in various lewd poses.

He also asked what positions she would want to try, and promised to be ‚Äúsuper gentle‚Äù when taking her virginity.¬†

The next day, Verity continued to message the decoy through the school day, and was later confronted outside his place of work by the group that afternoon.

During the hour-long confrontation, Verity admitted on-camera to messaging the decoy, having cloud access to a ‚Äúmega‚Äù stash of child porn, and bizarrely blaming his sex-less marriage for his sick online tendencies.¬†

Verity is set to be be arraigned Saturday.¬†

The Shoreham-Wading River school district could not be immediately reached for comment.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: ‰∫∫Â§¥ÔºåË∫ØÂπ≤Ë¢´ÂèëÁé∞ÂÄæÂÄíÂú®Â∏ÉÈ≤ÅÂÖãÊûóÁöÑÂûÉÂúæË¢ã‰∏≠
item.description:
A human head and torso were found in a trash bag outside a Brooklyn home early Friday morning, police said.¬†¬†

The body parts were left lying on a sidewalk near 557 E. 21st St.¬†in Flatbush and discovered¬†at 9:14 a.m.

According to sources, 311 was first called with complaints of a ‚Äúfoul odor‚Äù coming from apartment 6F before the call was rerouted to 911 to police.¬†

Police responded and determined the remains belonged to a dead man, authorities said.¬†

The building super allegedly saw the boyfriend of the dead man dumping the bags outside the location before the body was found, sources said..¬†

The city Office of Chief Medical Examiner will determine the cause of death or who the remains belong to, police said.

The investigation remains ongoing.
item.author: Erin Maher

item.title: PERVÂ®ÅËÉÅÂºïËØ±‰∏≠Â≠¶ÁîüËøõÂÖ•Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂÖ¨Âõ≠ÔºåËÆ©ÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥ËÑ±ÊéâË°¨Ë°´ÔºöÊ∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫ê
item.description:
The perv who allegedly targeted a teen on the way to school in the Bronx Thursday coerced her into a wooded area by threatening to expose embarrassing photos of her ‚Äì and then made her strip off her shirt before committing a lewd act and then offering her $20, law enforcement sources said.

Oneil Kennedy, 45, approached the 14-year-old victim as she walked to the nearby Bronx Alliance Middle School around 8:20 a.m., authorities and sources said.¬†

He allegedly forced her into a secluded area in Seton Falls Park with the threat, ‚ÄúI have a picture of you and your friends. If you don‚Äôt want me to show it, follow me,‚Äù the sources said.¬†

Once there, the sicko allegedly told the girl to lift up her shirt before masturbating in front of her, authorities and sources said.¬†

He then gave the shaken teen $20 and told her, ‚ÄúI will see you on Monday before fleeing,‚Äù according to the sources.

The victim ‚Äì who was not physically injured ‚Äì then showed up at her school and reported the incident to her teacher, the sources said.¬†

Cops caught up to Kennedy about 11 hours later, and he was charged with endangering the welfare of a child, public lewdness, stalking and harassment, police said.

Kennedy has seven prior arrests, including a Bronx forcible touching bust from 2010, where the victim was only 16, cops said.¬†

The latest attack came about a month after another Bronx sicko ‚Äî Xavier Chapman, 30 ‚Äî allegedly stormed up to a 19-year-old woman sitting on a park bench in Belmont and forced himself on her, authorities said.

He was arrested and charged with rape, sexual abuse and harassment, police said.¬†

And in Brooklyn, alleged serial creep Justin Lee, 22, tried to rape a 12-year-old girl inside a Coney Island apartment building earlier this month ‚Äî less than a week after he was sprung without bail in a pair of eerily similar attacks, authorities said.
item.author: Joe Marino, Amanda Woods

item.title: Zohran MamdaniÁöÑÈ°∂Á∫ßÂëòÂ∑•Ë¢´Êäì‰ΩèËØ¥‚ÄúË∞ÅÂú®‰πé‚ÄùË≠¶ÂØüÂØπÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈïøÈ¢ÜË∑ëËÄÖÁöÑÁúãÊ≥ïÔºöËßÜÈ¢ë
item.description:
A top campaign staffer for Zohran Mamdani was apparently caught on hidden camera admitting ‚Äúwho gives a s‚Äìt‚Äù what police officers think of the Democratic mayoral nominee.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre city employees. You get told what to do, shut up,‚Äù Robert Akleh, a progressive political consultant and the citywide canvass manager for the campaign, says in the clip.

‚ÄúWhen did you get an opinion?‚Äù he can be seen telling an ‚Äúundercover‚Äù operative for conservative podcaster Steven Crowder about NYPD cops‚Äô opinion of the front-runner socialist candidate.

The high-ranking field organizer also bashed Gov. Kathy Hochul and ‚ÄúIsrael supporting‚Äù Democrats to the ‚ÄúLouder with Crowder‚Äù spy.

Akleh appears to have been recorded making the statements at bars on different occasions in August and September.

Mamdani‚Äôs campaign didn‚Äôt immediately comment.
item.author: Vaughn Golden

item.title: ÈïøÂ≤õÁî∑Â≠êÔºå 21Â≤ÅÔºåË¢´ÊéßÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÈÖíÂêßÂ§ñÊùÄÂÆ≥ÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥ÔºåÂú®ÊâøËÆ§ÂêéËá™Áî±Ë°åËµ∞
item.description:
The Long Island man charged with killing a New Jersey high school football player outside a downtown ax-throwing bar was acquitted by a Manhattan jury ‚Äî even after admitting to the fatal stabbing on the witness stand.

Gianluca Bordone, 21, was found not guilty of manslaughter and assault charges Thursday after convincing jurors that he acted in self-defense when he stabbed 17-year-old Rocco Rodden in the heart outside the Live Axe nightclub in TriBeCa the night before Thanksgiving 2023.

The three-week trial included a handful of witnesses who testified about the drunken, early morning melee where Bordone, an Oyster Bay event promoter, plunged a pocket knife into Rodden‚Äôs chest as both groups of friends fought.

‚ÄúHe inflicted the fatal blow, a fatal wound in the center of his chest that ripped through his rib cage and cut open his heart,‚Äù Manhattan prosecutors said at trial.

Bordone‚Äôs attorney, Anthony Ricco, told jurors that video of the Nov. 23, 2023, brawl would prove his client‚Äôs actions were justified as Rodden‚Äôs crew chased him down the block and started ‚Äúbeating the crap out of him.‚Äù

Bordone took to the witness stand Monday and told the jury that he stabbed Rodden ‚Äî a high school junior and football player ‚Äî because he feared for his life, according to Newsday.

‚ÄúI was afraid that they would get me to the floor, stomp me, kill me, hit me with the bottle that I had seen before,‚Äù he said.

The trial included emotional testimony from Rodden‚Äôs family members, including his 21-year-old brother Anthony, who was also slashed by Bordone during the brawl.

Anthony told jurors that his younger brother and sister joined others in the city to celebrate a reunion back from college for the first time ‚Äî and testified to having been drinking heavily at the time of the stabbing.

Dramatic police bodycam footage played at trial showed a bloodied and shirtless Anthony screaming ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs my brother! Where‚Äôs my f‚Äìking brother!‚Äù as EMS tried to get him to a hospital for his own slash wounds after the 1:30 a.m. fight.

The jury needed just four hours before they returned their verdict to Manhattan Supreme Court Justice Laura Ward Thursday.

Bordone, who graduated from Roslyn High School, was facing up to 25 years in prison if convicted of first-degree manslaughter.

His attorney did not immediately return request for comment Friday.

A spokesperson for the Manhattan District Attorney‚Äôs Office thanked jurors for their service and extended their condolences to the Rodden family.

‚ÄúWe thank the members of the jury for their service and respect their verdict,‚Äù the spokesperson said. ‚ÄúWe extend our deepest sympathies to the Rodden family, who continue to mourn a devastating loss.‚Äù
item.author: Kyle Schnitzer

item.title: Ë¢´ÊåáÊéßÁöÑÊÄßË¥©ËøêËÄÖÁöÑÂ¶ªÂ≠êÈúçÂçéÂæ∑¬∑È≤ÅÂÆæÔºà Howard Rubin ÔºâÂ£∞Áß∞‰ªñÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆ∂Â∫≠Áî∑‰∫∫ÔºåÂ∫îËØ•‰ª•5000‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÁöÑ‰øùËØÅÈáëËé∑ÂæóÈáäÊîæ
item.description:
Former financier and accused depraved sex trafficker Howard Rubin is actually a loving grandfather who should be freed on a $50 million bond, his estranged wife said in new court documents.

Mary Henry wrote a letter to the court late Thursday urging the judge to spring multi-millionaire retired bond trader Howard Rubin, 70, on the whopping bail package so that he can continue spending time with his three young grandchildren while awaiting trial.

‚ÄúI understand far too well the serious charges before the court,‚Äù Henry wrote. ‚ÄúI can only speak from my own experience when I say they do not represent the Howie Rubin I saw: a caring father, a loving son-in-law, and devoted grandfather known affectionately as ‚ÄòPops.‚Äô

‚ÄúHe would never abandon his family. He has always placed them at the center of his life, and they remain his greatest source of strength,‚Äù she wrote to federal Judge Brian Cogan.

Rubin ‚Äî once a high-flying trader at Solomon Brothers and for George Soros‚Äô investment firm ‚Äî has been locked up in a Brooklyn jail since his Sept. 26 arrest on shocking charges of sex trafficking models in a Midtown ‚Äúdungeon.‚Äù

Federal prosecutors have accused Rubin of luring ‚Äúdozens‚Äù of women to New York City between 2009 and 2019, where he¬†allegedly tied them up, beat and electrocuted them.

The Brooklyn US Attorney‚Äôs Office maintains that Rubin is both a danger to the community and a flight risk, and that he should stay locked up in Sunset Park‚Äôs Metropolitan Detention Center.

His arrest came as a ‚Äú‚Äòrelief‚Äù to one of his accusers, who told The Post ‚Äúthank God‚Äù when told he‚Äôd been held without bail.

Henry, 74, filed for divorce from Rubin in 2021, but the pair still help take care of their grandkids and attend family events together with their three adult children, she wrote in her letter to the judge.

She has agreed to put up her Connecticut home, in which she has $1.6 million in equity, as collateral in the event that Rubin fails to show up to court, his defense attorney said in a court filing.

Rubin‚Äôs brother, Jonathan Rubin, has agreed to put his Connecticut home on the line as well, the lawyers wrote, noting the jailed financier had been taking his grandkids to weekly swimming lessons before his arrest.

‚ÄúHis dedication as a grandfather is also recognized throughout the community; he brings his grandchildren to swimming and dance lessons weekly, forging strong relationships with instructors and other families,‚Äù lawyer Benjamin Rosenberg wrote.

Rubin is expected to appear in Brooklyn federal court Monday. The judge said he would set a separate hearing date to consider the bail proposal.

Rubin‚Äôs former assistant and co-defendant Jennifer Powers, 45, has been released on a personal recognizance bond and is due in court on Monday as well.
item.author: Ben Kochman

item.title: ÊØîÂ∞î¬∑ËÄÉÊñØÊØîÔºà Bill Cosby ÔºâÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇËÅîÊéíÂà´Â¢ÖË¢´ÂèñÊ∂àÊäµÊäºÂìÅËµéÂõûÊùÉÔºå‰∏äÂ∏Ç‰∏çÂà∞‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúàÂ∞±ÊâæÂà∞‰∫Ü‰π∞ÂÆ∂
item.description:
Less than a month after hitting the market, Bill Cosby‚Äôs longtime Upper East Side townhouse has already landed a buyer, The Post has learned.

The limestone-clad property at 18 E. 71st St. ‚Äî listed for $29 million with Corcoran ‚Äî went into contract on Thursday, Oct. 16, according to StreetEasy records.

The sale price remains under wraps, but the deal marks the latest twist in a turbulent chapter for the disgraced entertainer and his wife, Camille.

Court documents filed earlier this year accused the couple of defaulting on $17.5 million in loans tied to the residence.

The 13,000-square-foot mansion, designed in 1899 by architect John Duncan ‚Äî the mind behind Grant‚Äôs Tomb ‚Äî stands among the Upper East Side‚Äôs grandest Gilded Age holdouts.

Its ornate limestone fa√ßade, copper mansard roof, and proximity to Central Park give it an enduring allure, even as its ownership story turned fraught.

Cosby acquired the home in 1987 for $6.2 million during the height of his NBC fame, reportedly as a surprise for his wife.

Then known as the Luyster Mansion, the property exemplifies the stately neo-French Classic style that once dominated Manhattan‚Äôs wealthiest streets.

A few doors away sits the former townhouse of Jeffrey Epstein, which sold in 2021 for $51 million ‚Äî a reminder that even scandal hasn‚Äôt dulled the block‚Äôs market appeal.

Still, the listing made no mention of Cosby or the financial entanglements surrounding the estate.

According to a Manhattan Supreme Court filing, the couple allegedly stopped making mortgage payments in June 2024 and owe more than $300,000 in property taxes. The lender, First Foundation Bank, initiated foreclosure proceedings last year ‚Äî claims the Cosbys have denied in court.

Inside, the home reflects its turn-of-the-century grandeur.

A marble-lined vestibule opens into a soaring central hall with 15-foot ceilings. A 500-square-foot parlor features inlaid mahogany floors and one of 11 fireplaces. French doors overlook East 71st Street, while a restored mahogany-and-bronze elevator services multiple levels.

A double-height drawing room showcases herringbone parquet floors and 20-foot ceilings, while the dining room below can host up to 30 guests. The adjoining chef‚Äôs kitchen ‚Äî once part of the former Lyc√©e Fran√ßais ‚Äî includes terracotta tile, beveled glass cabinetry and a restaurant-grade rotisserie oven.

Upstairs, the primary suite offers dual bathrooms beneath vaulted skylights. The top floor houses a quiet study and a guest suite with access to a private terrace.

Above it all, a 500-square-foot roof garden provides rare outdoor space in one of Manhattan‚Äôs most exclusive enclaves.

Public records trace a complex ownership history: Cosby‚Äôs initial purchase was handled through an attorney before being transferred to Camille‚Äôs mother and eventually into the couple‚Äôs names.

In 1990, the Cosbys accused their former lawyer, Mary Waller, of embezzling funds from that transaction ‚Äî an early sign of the financial disputes that would follow them for decades.

The East 71st Street mansion isn‚Äôt the only property tied to the couple‚Äôs mounting debt.

In December, CitiMortgage filed a separate suit alleging default on a $4.2 million loan connected to another townhouse at 243 E. 61st St., which the Cosbys purchased in 1980. That four-story property was listed in April for $7 million and later reduced by roughly $250,000 over the summer as legal battles intensified.

Cosby, now 88, continues to live in the shadow of his 2018 sexual-assault conviction ‚Äî overturned three years later by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court ‚Äî and the accusations of more than 60 women.

A spokesperson for the Cosbys declined to comment on the sale.
item.author: Mary K. Jacob

item.title: Êâ≠Êõ≤ÁöÑÂè≤Âù¶È°øÂ≤õÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥Âú®Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ¨°‰∫≤Ëá™Âá∫Â∫≠Êó∂ËØ°ÂºÇÂú∞ÁõØÁùÄÊçÆÁß∞Êñ©È¶ñÂ¶àÂ¶àÁöÑÁî∑ÊúãÂèã
item.description:
The twisted Staten Island teen accused of decapitating his mom‚Äôs boyfriend eerily stared, with an oddly calm expression on his face, as he pleaded not guilty to the gruesome murder Friday.

Damien Hurstel, 19, shuffled unbothered into a Richmond County courtroom, for the first time since he allegedly killed, beheaded and mutilated Anthony Casalaspro, 45, last week inside their shared West Brighton home.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Hurstel, his messy hair covering one eye, said as Judge Raymond Rodriguez asked if he was pleading not guilty to the murder charge ‚Äî the only word he uttered during the hearing.

Seven of his family members quietly sat in the courtroom as the gaunt teen walked in, clad in a rumpled orange jumpsuit and bearing a distant, strangely serene expression.

The apparently mentally ill Hurstel had previously been arraigned by video from a hospital bed days after allegedly stabbing, killing and butchering Casalaspro ‚Äî a sanitation worker ‚Äî on Oct. 6.

A blood-soaked Hurstel allegedly showed his 16-year-old little sister the mutilated body during a horrific encounter inside their Cary Avenue home.

Their mother, Alicia Zayas, previously told The Post that Hurstel tried to explain what happened.

‚ÄúHow he was going to fix everything, like it could be fixed,‚Äù Zayas said in disbelief, tears streaming down her face.

Hurstel‚Äôs sister ran outside, hid and made a chilling call to Zayas.

‚ÄúShe said, ‚ÄòDamien killed Anthony, and he doesn‚Äôt have a head,'‚Äù Zayas said.

A grisly crime scene photo shows Casalaspro‚Äôs severed head lying next to his corpse inside the home‚Äôs walk-in shower, with a bowl and a saw on the floor nearby.

The handle of a silver-colored spoon could be seen sticking out of the dismembered skull, along with a plastic sauce ladle on the dismembered body‚Äôs chest, the photo shows.

Law-enforcement sources said Hurstel allegedly confessed, telling cops he planned to dispose of Casalaspro‚Äôs body by cutting it into pieces and pulverizing the parts in a blender, starting with the brain.

In court, Hurstel didn‚Äôt appear affected by the horror of his alleged crime.

He stared straight ahead without trying to move his head to sweep his wavy hair from covering his eye.
Raymond, the judge, ordered that Hurstel stay jailed and continue receiving medical attention and psychiatric care, as well as remain on suicide watch.

Hurstel is next scheduled to appear in court Nov. 20.

Zayas declined to comment after the hearing.
item.author: Khristina Narizhnaya, Matt Troutman

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Áª¥Âü∫ÁôæÁßë‰ºöËÆÆÂú®‚ÄúÈùûÁäØÁΩ™ÁöÑÊÅãÁ´•ÁôñËÄÖ‚ÄùÈ£éÊö¥Èò∂ÊÆµÂÅúÊ≠¢ÔºåÁî®Êû™ÊåáÁùÄËá™Â∑±ÁöÑÂ§¥
item.description:
A Wikipedia conference in Manhattan descended into chaos Friday morning when an unhinged Ohio man jumped on stage and pointed a gun at his own head.

Connor Weston ‚Äî who had a multicolored banner draped over his shoulders and a sign around his neck with the words ‚ÄúANTI-CONTACT NON-OFFENDING PEDOPHILE‚Äù ‚Äî was tackled and disarmed by WikiConference staff before being taken into custody by police, sources said.

He was detained at the conference, which was hosted at the Hyatt Place Chelsea at 24th Street and 7th Avenue, according to the NYPD‚Äôs 9th Precinct, where he is awaiting charges.

Weston, from Dayton, had registered for the conference, which was being held in New York this year to celebrate the city‚Äôs 400th anniversary,¬†according to the event page.

In a late June post on X, he explained that he is ‚Äúfundamentally against adult/minor relations because I know that they are harmful.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have any ‚Äòurges‚Äô that I have to control, just like how most straight men don‚Äôt have the urge to rape every woman they meet,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúPedophilia is not a choice. I can choose to not harm minors, but I cannot choose to stop being attracted to them.‚Äù
item.author: Amanda Woods, Joe Marino

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈïøËæ©ËÆ∫ÁöÑÂâç5‰∏™Êó∂ÂàªÔºöË¢≠Âáª„ÄÅÂò≤Á¨ëÂíåÁãÇÈáéÊïÖ‰∫ã
item.description:
The first mayoral general election debate was two hours filled with attacks, jibes and wild stories as Zohran Mamdani, Curtis Sliwa and Andrew Cuomo went all out to make their mark.

The three candidates in the Nov. 4 election frequently talked over each other ‚Äî and a few times Sliwa, the Republican candidate, also droned on so much that the moderators at 30 Rockefeller Center cut him off.

Sliwa and Cuomo, the former governor running as an independent, aimed much of their ire at the front-runner, Democratic nominee Mamdani ‚Äî but weren‚Äôt always in sync with their attacks.

Here are the top five moments from Thursday‚Äôs debate on WNBC:

1. ‚ÄúHe literally never had a job.‚Äù

Cuomo wasted no time ripping into Mamdani. Within minutes of the start of the debate, he jabbed at the Queens assemblyman‚Äôs lack of leadership experience.

‚ÄúHe literally has never had a job,‚Äù Cuomo said.

‚ÄúOn his resume, it says he interned for his mother. This is not a job for a first-timer,‚Äù Cuomo said, comparing the 33-year-old assemblyman to his decades-long career in elected politics.

‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre doing people could die,‚Äù he continued.

Mamdani, meanwhile, was quick to point out the death toll during the COVID-19 pandemic, when Cuomo was governor.

‚ÄúIf we have a health pandemic, then why would New Yorkers turn back to the governor who sent seniors to their deaths in nursing homes?,‚Äù he retorted.

2. ‚ÄúThe jawns, the madames and the pimps‚Äù

Mamdani‚Äôs stance on prostitution, one of the most shocking aspects of the democratic socialists‚Äô agenda, was bound to be one of the most fiery points of the evening, and did not disappoint.

During a separate line of questions on quality of life, Sliwa and Cuomo started digging into Mamdani, accusing him of wanting to let hookers run free for hire.

‚ÄúThe assemblyman is a mini-me-BDB, he‚Äôs Bill de Blasio-lite,‚Äù Cuomo said, accusing Mamdani of adopting the former mayor‚Äôs direction to NYPD not to arrest prostitutes.

‚ÄúI am not nor have I ever called for the legalization of prostitution,‚Äù Mamdani claimed, digging into Cuomo.

Mamdani wants to decriminalize sex work and co-sponsors a bill in Albany that would do so.

‚ÄúIf you are happy with what‚Äôs happening on Roosevelt Avenue then you should vote for Andrew Cuomo because his policy is to continue the exact same ones we‚Äôve seen under [current mayor] Eric Adams,‚Äù Mamdani added.

Cuomo has advocated for flooding cops to areas like notorious avenue of sweethearts, and prosecuting prostitutes.

‚ÄúYou have to enforce the law, it‚Äôs illegal.‚Äù

Sliwa stuck out a middle ground, advocating for focusing on going after the pimps and men hiring prostitutes instead of the women themselves.

‚ÄúYou let everybody know about the jawns. The madams and the pimps need to be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law,‚Äù Sliwa said.

3. Nobody likes Kathy

None of the candidates were willing to publicly back Gov. Kathy Hochul‚Äôs reelection bid next year.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a decision that should be made after this general election,‚Äù Mamdani said, seeming to defend his newfound benefactor in Hochul.

The upstate governor delivered a shocking and controversial endorsement of the Queens pol last month.

Little love is lost between Hochul and Cuomo, who it has emerged had wanted to boot Hochul as his running mate had he followed through with a reelection campaign in 2022.

‚ÄúYou have to know who‚Äôs running,‚Äù Cuomo said when prodded by the moderator for an answer before shifting the question back to Mamdani.

‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you endorse her?‚Äù Cuomo asked.

4. Mamdani can‚Äôt explain how to pay for his freebies

Put on the spot and asked to explain how the city would be able to afford his handout-packed ‚Äúaffordability‚Äù agenda, Mamdani once again fell on a word salad.

‚ÄúLook, a lot of people have called even my campaign a non-starter when we first again and now I stand before you proud to be the Democratic nominee who got the most votes in city primary history,‚Äù the assemblyman said, dodging the question.

Mamdani‚Äôs handouts include free buses, universal child care and freezing rent for stabilized units.

‚ÄúWe have also put forward a plan to save money here in New York City,‚Äù he said, referring to his ‚Äúplan B‚Äù if Hochul won‚Äôt allow him to raise taxes.

5. Unexpected parade controversy

A seemingly innocuous question about whether the candidates would boycott any parades turned into more controversy.

‚ÄúNo, I wouldn‚Äôt unless they discriminated,‚Äù Cuomo said succinctly.

‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt thought much about parades to be honest with you,‚Äù Mamdani said before Sliwa jumped in to press him.

‚ÄúWould you protect the Christopher Columbus statues that exist here in the city?‚Äù Sliwa asked, bringing up how Mamdani once gave the middle finger to a monument to Columbus in Astoria.

‚ÄúMy focus is on affordability. I‚Äôm not thinking about statues,‚Äù Mamdani said.

‚ÄúDisgraziato!‚Äù Cuomo chimed in, following Sliwa‚Äôs lead.

The moderators quickly pivoted to asking the candidates about their preferred bagel order before wrapping the two-hour debate.

Bonus: Sliwa‚Äôs outbursts

Even without his iconic red ‚ÄúGuardian Angels‚Äù beret, GOP mayoral candidate Curtis Sliwa was his usual self, injecting wild, dated anecdotes and his own memorable one-liners into the mix as well as some hard-hitting zingers aimed seemingly indiscriminately at all sides.

‚ÄúI knew Mario Cuomo, you‚Äôre no Mario Cuomo,‚Äù Sliwa told Cuomo of his late father, also a former governor.

Sliwa also compared the state parole board under Andrew Cuomo having released 43 cop killers, compared to none under his father.

The Guardian Angel leader did not disappoint throughout the debate, with other noteworthy moments including:

  • Saying he avoids taking yellow cabs because he was shot by the mob in the back of one in the 1970s
  • Confirming he smoked medical marijuana as he dealt with Crohn‚Äôs disease after that yellow cab shooting
  • Starting to respond to a question directed to Cuomo
  • Name-dropping his ex-wife, Queens DA Melinda Katz
  • Naming former Republican Governor George Pataki when asked his favorite president
item.author: Vaughn Golden

item.title: ‚ÄúNEPO BABY‚Äù Zohran MamdaniÊÉ≥Ë°®Áé∞Âá∫ÂØπAndrew CuomoÁöÑ‚ÄúÂº∫Á°¨‚Äù ÔºöË∫´‰Ωì‰∏ìÂÆ∂
item.description:
Democrat socialist and self-described ‚Äúnepo-baby‚Äù Zohran Mamdani fronted the first general mayoral election debate desperately wanting voters ‚Äúto see him as tough‚Äù as he threw punches at his ‚Äúbedraggled‚Äù rival, ex-Gov. Andrew Cuomo, a body language expert told The Post.

‚ÄúMamdani was, ironically or purposefully, dressed in black like a villain,‚Äù brain and¬†body language expert¬†and psychiatrist Carole¬†Lieberman said in the wake of Thursday night‚Äôs showdown.

‚ÄúHe was either showing his true colors unconsciously or wanted viewers to see him as tough.‚Äù

The 33-year-old upstart ‚Äî whose mom is an Academy Award- and Golden Globe-nominated filmmaker, and whose dad is an author and chaired professor at Columbia University ‚Äî has even joked that he has benefited from nepotism.

He has also come under scrutiny for his short resume and lack of experience in local government.

Lieberman said the mayoral frontrunner was smug, too, as he jostled with Cuomo, who is running as an independent, and Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa, ahead of next month‚Äôs election.

‚ÄúHe also perpetually wore a cat-that-ate-the-canary, smug smile, as if he was already thinking about how he would decorate the Mayor‚Äôs mansion,‚Äù the expert said ‚Äî though she noted the socialist upstart seemed ‚Äúa little more nervous‚Äù than usual.

‚ÄúHe seemed angry, as if annoyed that he still had to debate to prove he‚Äôs the best candidate. His tense anger was made visible by his clenched jaw, erratic hand gestures and squinting,‚Äù Lieberman said.

Cuomo, on the other hand, looked worse for wear.

‚Äú[He] looks bedraggled. He could pass for a homeless person on a Central Park bench,‚Äù Lieberman noted, adding that the stress of the campaign was taking a visible toll.

‚ÄúHe looks almost sickly,‚Äù she added.

By the end of the debate, the former governor ‚Äúlooked worried‚Äù like ‚Äúhe feared he hadn‚Äôt gotten enough of an edge over Mamdani,‚Äù the expert said.

In direct contrast, Sliwa¬†‚Äî who was sans his iconic red beret ‚Äî was the ‚Äúmost relaxed and friendly‚Äù of all three candidates.

‚ÄúHis wide arms, on either side of the podium, indicated that he was also the most open,‚Äù Lieberman noted.

‚ÄúHe was a welcome island of calm, a respite for viewers from Cuomo and Mamdani, who made viewers nervous.

‚ÄúHis clothing mirrored his calmer attitude,‚Äù she added.

A Fox News poll released just before the debate started showed Mamdani breaking 50% for the first time in the contentious race so far.

The democratic socialist garnered 52% of likely voters, with Cuomo and Sliwa trailing at 28% and 14%, respectively,¬†the poll showed.
item.author: Emily Crane

item.title: SayvilleÊòéÊòü‰ø°Âè∑ÂëºÂè´ËÄÖPatrick CoanÂú®ÂâçNotre Dame QBË°®Â¶πÁöÑÊåáÂØº‰∏ãËì¨ÂãÉÂèëÂ±ï
item.description:
Patrick Coan is leading Sayville onward to victory.

The senior quarterback, whose cousin is former Notre Dame QB Jack Coan, is enjoying an undefeated season with his Golden Flashes as they attempt to go to 6-0 with a win against rival Westhampton this weekend.

‚ÄúEvery day is just a blast. Going out there, playing football, and having fun with your dogs,‚Äù Coan, 17, told The Post of his teammates.

Sayville, which went undefeated last year until a crushing 31-28 loss to juggernaut Garden City in the Long Island title game, has a chip on its shoulder to get the job done this year.

‚ÄúWe just reloaded with a great new group of guys, and we‚Äôre all ready to play football,‚Äù added the Lehigh commit. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just balling right now, and hoping to keep that going.‚Äù

Jack, now playing with the Saskatchewan Roughriders in the CFL, has always been close with Patrick, showed him the ropes ahead of his senior year and continues to be a mentor.

‚ÄúWe go down to the field and he teaches me footwork, reads, progressions, and everything. Every morning on the weekends, we‚Äôd go down to the field, even when it‚Äôs cold or warm,‚Äù said Patrick.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs definitely a great trainer and a great mentor. He teaches the game very well.‚Äù

The older Coan, a class of 2017 grad who led the Flashes to an LI championship win in 2015 before playing at Wisconsin and later ND, is paying it forward to the entire varsity squad, too.

‚ÄúSaskatchewan was on a bye, and he had flown into town, and he sent me a text, ‚ÄòHey, I‚Äôd love to come to practice,‚Äô ‚Äù said head coach Robert Hoss, who has coached both of the cousins.

‚ÄúHe said to me, ‚ÄòHey, Coach, can you add me to your Hudl account? I‚Äôd love to watch practice and games‚Ä¶ He wants to wear Sayville football gear. It‚Äôs really cool, and our kids love to see that.‚Äô‚Äù

Patrick, in particular, is being motivated by the family presence that‚Äôs shaking down the thunder on the South Shore, according to his coach.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no doubt Patrick knows Jack is watching, and he is the ultimate positive guy. Even if he was going to give Patrick constructive feedback, it would always be in a positive way,‚Äù Hoss said.

‚ÄúHaving that connection, he can walk him through certain things ‚Ä¶ and I think that‚Äôs helped Patrick tremendously.‚Äù

Now, the sights are set on the Flashes rewriting the script in what will be the younger Coan‚Äôs last dance in Sayville.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt really focus on like the whole pressure thing,‚Äù Patrick said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just going out there having fun and playing football, which we all love to do.‚Äù
item.author: Alex Mitchell
